title: Miranda v. Arizona
shortDescription: Landmark case establishing the requirement for police to inform suspects of their rights.
facts: Ernesto Miranda was arrested and interrogated by police without being informed of his constitutional rights. He confessed to crimes during the interrogation. The confession was used against him at trial.
legalIssue: Whether statements obtained from a defendant during custodial interrogation are admissible if the defendant was not informed of their constitutional rights.

precedents.name: Escobedo v. Illinois (1964)
precedents.relevance: Established right to counsel during interrogation

petitioner: Fifth Amendment protection against self-incrimination requires warnings
Sixth Amendment guarantees right to counsel
Coercive nature of custodial interrogation necessitates safeguards
respondent: No constitutional requirement for specific warnings

outcome: The Supreme Court ruled 5-4 that the prosecution may not use statements from custodial interrogation unless procedural safeguards are in place.
practiceQuestions: What are the four Miranda warnings?
When must Miranda warnings be given?
What happens if police fail to give Miranda warnings?

title: Brown v. Board of Education
shortDescription: Declared state laws establishing separate public schools for black and white students unconstitutional.
facts: Black children were denied admission to public schools attended by white children under laws requiring racial segregation. The plaintiffs argued that segregated schools were not equal and could never be made equal.
legalIssue: Does segregation of children in public schools solely on the basis of race deprive minority children of equal educational opportunities?

precedents.name: Plessy v. Ferguson (1896)
precedents.relevance: Established 'separate but equal' doctrine - to be overturned

precedents.name: Sweatt v. Painter (1950)
precedents.relevance: Found inequality in segregated law schools

petitioner: Segregation violates Equal Protection Clause of 14th Amendment
Separate educational facilities are inherently unequal
Segregation generates feeling of inferiority affecting motivation to learn
Modern psychological knowledge shows harm of segregation
respondent: Plessy v. Ferguson precedent supports separate but equal
States have right to regulate education
Social customs should not be changed by judicial decree

outcome: Unanimous decision that separate educational facilities are inherently unequal, violating the Equal Protection Clause.
practiceQuestions: How did this case overturn Plessy v. Ferguson?
What role did social science evidence play?
What was the implementation timeline ordered by the Court?

title: Roe v. Wade
shortDescription: Established constitutional right to abortion under the right to privacy.
facts: Jane Roe, a pregnant single woman, challenged Texas criminal abortion laws that prohibited abortion except to save the mother's life. She claimed the laws were unconstitutionally vague and violated her right to privacy.
legalIssue: Does the Constitution recognize a woman's right to terminate her pregnancy by abortion?

petitioner: Right to privacy encompasses abortion decision
Absolute ban violates Due Process Clause
Woman's right to control her own body
respondent: State has compelling interest in protecting potential life
No explicit constitutional right to abortion
State has duty to protect prenatal life
Medical procedures can be regulated by state

outcome: 7-2 decision establishing trimester framework balancing woman's privacy rights with state's interests in maternal health and potential life.
practiceQuestions: What is the trimester framework established by this case?
How does the Court balance competing interests?
What level of scrutiny was applied?

title: Donoghue v. Stevenson
shortDescription: Established the modern law of negligence and the neighbor principle.
facts: Mrs. Donoghue consumed ginger beer from an opaque bottle that allegedly contained a decomposed snail. She became ill and sued the manufacturer, though she had no contract with them.
legalIssue: Does a manufacturer owe a duty of care to the ultimate consumer with whom they have no contractual relationship?

petitioner: Manufacturer owes duty to ultimate consumer
Products should be safe for intended use
respondent: No duty owed beyond immediate purchaser
Intervening parties break chain of liability

outcome: House of Lords established that manufacturers owe a duty of care to consumers, creating the 'neighbor principle' in negligence law.
practiceQuestions: What is the neighbor principle?
Why was the bottle being opaque significant?
How did this case change tort law?

title: Carlill v. Carbolic Smoke Ball Company
shortDescription: Landmark case on unilateral contracts and advertisements as offers.
facts: The Carbolic Smoke Ball Company advertised that it would pay £100 to anyone who contracted influenza after using its product as directed. Mrs. Carlill used the product but still contracted influenza and claimed the reward.
legalIssue: Can an advertisement constitute a binding unilateral contract offer?

precedents.name: Williams v. Carwardine (1833)
precedents.relevance: Motive for acceptance irrelevant if conditions met

petitioner: Advertisement was a serious offer, not mere puff
Performed conditions by using product as directed
respondent: Advertisement was mere puff, not legal offer
Offer not made to specific person

outcome: Court held the advertisement was a valid offer and Mrs. Carlill's use of the product constituted acceptance, creating a binding contract.
practiceQuestions: What distinguishes an offer from an invitation to treat?
Why was notification of acceptance not required?
What made this a unilateral contract?

title: Salomon v. Salomon & Co Ltd
shortDescription: Established the principle of corporate separate legal personality.
facts: Aron Salomon incorporated his boot-making business, with himself and family members as shareholders. When the company became insolvent, creditors argued the company was merely Salomon's agent and he should be personally liable.
legalIssue: Is a validly incorporated company a separate legal entity distinct from its shareholders?

precedents.name: Foss v. Harbottle (1843)
precedents.relevance: Company as separate entity can sue and be sued

petitioner: Company validly incorporated under Companies Act
Separate legal personality is fundamental principle
respondent: Company was mere sham or facade

outcome: House of Lords held that a validly incorporated company is a separate legal person, establishing the cornerstone of modern corporate law.
practiceQuestions: What is the corporate veil?
When might courts pierce the corporate veil?
What are the implications for limited liability?

title: Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala
shortDescription: Established the basic structure doctrine limiting Parliament's power to amend the Constitution.
facts: A challenge to Kerala land reform laws and the constitutional amendments that sought to place them beyond judicial review. The case examined the extent of Parliament's power to amend the Constitution.
legalIssue: Can Parliament amend any part of the Constitution, including fundamental rights, or are there implied limitations?

precedents.name: Golaknath v. State of Punjab (1967)
precedents.relevance: Held Parliament cannot amend fundamental rights

precedents.name: Shankari Prasad v. Union of India (1951)

petitioner: Constitution has basic features that cannot be amended
Fundamental rights are core to Constitution

outcome: Supreme Court held that while Parliament can amend the Constitution, it cannot alter its 'basic structure', creating a landmark doctrine in constitutional law.
practiceQuestions: What constitutes the 'basic structure' of the Constitution?
How does this doctrine balance democracy and constitutionalism?
What is the significance of this case for judicial review?

title: R v. Dudley and Stephens
shortDescription: Examined the defense of necessity in a murder case involving survival cannibalism.
facts: After their ship sank, four crew members were stranded in a lifeboat. After 20 days without food, Dudley and Stephens killed and ate the cabin boy. They were rescued four days later.
legalIssue: Can necessity be a defense to murder when killing another to preserve one's own life?

petitioner: Custom of the sea recognized practice
respondent: No legal justification for taking innocent life
Who decides whose life is worth less?

outcome: Court held that necessity is not a defense to murder, though the defendants' death sentences were commuted to six months imprisonment.
practiceQuestions: Why did the court reject the necessity defense?
What are the moral implications of this decision?
How does this case relate to modern trolley problems?

title: Hadley v. Baxendale
shortDescription: Established the rule for remoteness of damages in contract law.
facts: Hadley's mill was stopped by a broken crankshaft. Baxendale was hired to transport it for repair but delayed delivery. Hadley sued for lost profits during the delay.
legalIssue: What damages are recoverable for breach of contract?

respondent: Not informed mill would be idle
Could not foresee extent of loss
Damages should be limited to direct loss

outcome: Court established two-limb test: damages must arise naturally from breach OR be in reasonable contemplation of both parties at contract formation.
practiceQuestions: What are the two limbs of the Hadley v. Baxendale test?
Why is foreseeability important in contract damages?
How does this differ from tort damages?

title: Marbury v. Madison
shortDescription: Established the principle of judicial review in the United States.
facts: William Marbury was appointed Justice of the Peace but his commission was not delivered. He petitioned the Supreme Court for a writ of mandamus to compel delivery.
legalIssue: Does the Supreme Court have the authority to review acts of Congress and declare them unconstitutional?

precedents.name: Hylton v. United States (1796)
precedents.relevance: Early case implying judicial review power

respondent: No constitutional basis for judicial review

outcome: Court held it has power to review congressional acts and declare them unconstitutional, but ruled against Marbury on jurisdictional grounds.
practiceQuestions: How did Marshall avoid political confrontation while establishing judicial review?
What is the constitutional basis for judicial review?
Why is this case considered foundational to American constitutional law?
